senses.de: To agree that something is true, especially unwillingly
senses.ex: He admitted that he had made a mistake.

Tips.title: Reluctant Agreement
Tips.description: Used when someone agrees to a truth they wish wasn’t true or hesitated to acknowledge.
Tips.example: After questioning, she finally admitted her jealousy.

Tips.title: Avoid Past Tense
Tips.description: Using 'admitted' might sound like a formal confession or a statement in legal contexts.
Tips.example: The defendant admitted the evidence was damning.

Tips.title: Not Always Negative
Tips.description: It can also be used for positive truths, although less common.
Tips.example: He admitted he was in love.

senses.de: To allow someone to enter a place

Tips.title: Physical Entry
Tips.description: Often pertains to the physical act of allowing someone into a location.
Tips.example: Sign here to admit guests into the building.

Tips.title: Event Specific
Tips.description: Commonly used in contexts like events, buildings, or rooms, indicating permission to enter.
Tips.example: The pass admits two to the concert.

senses.de: To accept someone into an organization or a group
senses.ex: She was admitted to the bar in 2000.

Tips.title: Formal Acceptance
Tips.description: Highlights a formal or official process of being accepted into a group or organization.
Tips.example: She felt proud to be admitted as a society member.

Tips.title: Milestone Achievement
Tips.description: Being admitted often signifies a significant achievement, like becoming a lawyer or doctor.
Tips.example: He was admitted to the engineers’ board.

senses.de: To allow the possibility of something
senses.ex: The theory admits of no exceptions.

Tips.title: Abstract Possibility
Tips.description: Can refer to the abstract idea of accepting a concept or a chance of something happening.
Tips.example: This hypothesis admits of multiple interpretations.

Tips.title: Expression of Doubt
Tips.description: Sometimes indicates doubt or suggests that other interpretations are possible.
Tips.example: His theory admits of no definitive proof.

senses.de: To send someone to a hospital for treatment
senses.ex: The patient was admitted to hospital last night with chest pains.

Tips.title: Medical Context
Tips.description: Used for patients entering a hospital to receive care, not just visiting.
Tips.example: The doctor decided to admit her immediately.

Tips.title: Severity Implication
Tips.description: Implies a serious concern that requires professional medical attention.
Tips.example: Due to the severity of his injuries, he was admitted.

Accept.wordDefinition:
Accept means to agree or take something that is offered or given, like accepting an invitation or accepting a gift. It's usually used in a positive way.

Both words can be used in different situations, but accept is more commonly used in a happy or positive circumstance, while admit is used when there is a more difficult or uncomfortable situation.

Acknowledge.wordDefinition:
Acknowledge means to recognize or accept something as true or real. This could be used in a situation where you are aware of a fact or situation and you are willing to acknowledge that it exists.

For example, you might acknowledge that your friend is upset about something.

Admit means to confess or acknowledge something that is seen as negative or embarrassing. This could be used in a situation where you are confessing to a mistake or wrongdoing.

So, in short, acknowledge is more neutral and can be used for any type of recognition, while admit is used for a more negative or embarrassing acknowledgment.

Allow.wordDefinition:
Allow is used when you give someone permission or grant them access to something. For example, "I'll allow you to borrow my book." It implies a sense of authority or control.

Admit is used when you confess something and allow is used when you give someone permission.

Concede.wordDefinition:
The words admit and concede are similar in meaning, but they have slight differences in their usage.

To concede means to surrender or acknowledge that something is true, valid or correct. It implies that you have lost an argument or discussion.

For example, if you and a friend are having a debate and they present a compelling argument, you might say, "I concede that you have a point."

Admit is used when acknowledging your own fault or mistake, whereas concede is used when acknowledging the strength or correctness of someone else's argument.

Confess.wordDefinition:
The words admit and confess are similar in meaning, but differ in their context of use.

Confess means to openly and voluntarily admit something wrong, often as a way of asking for forgiveness or expressing remorse.

For example, a person may confess to their friend about lying to them or someone may confess their feelings to a crush.

Admit is used in more serious or formal situations, while confess is used in more personal situations of admitting something wrong.

Grant.wordDefinition:
Grant means to give or allow something that is being requested or deserved.

For example, "the government granted the organization funding for their project" or "the university granted the student a scholarship for their academic achievements".

Admit is used to accept the truth or give permission to join, while grant is used to give or allow something, such as funding or a scholarship.

Permit.wordDefinition:
Permit means to give someone permission to do something. For example, if you want to go to a party, your parents might permit you to go if you finish your homework first.

Permit can also refer to a document or license that allows someone to do something. For example, a driver's permit allows someone to legally drive a car.

Admit is used when referring to access to a place or confessing something, while permit is used when referring to permission to do something or possessing a document that allows something.

Recognize.wordDefinition:
Admit is used to acknowledge and take responsibility for something that was done wrong or mistaken. For example, "I admit that I was wrong about my math answer." Recognize is used to identify something or someone that is familiar or known.

For example, "I recognize that face from the TV show."

Admit is used when someone wants to take responsibility for their actions or errors, while recognize is used when someone wants to identify or acknowledge something or someone familiar.

quotes.Text: I have to admit I've found myself doing the same things that a lot of other rock stars do or are forced to do. Which is not being able to respond to mail, not being able to keep up on current music, and I'm pretty much locked away a lot. The outside world is pretty foreign to me.
quotes.Title: American Singer
quotes.Name: Kurt Cobain

quotes.Text: We might be too proud to admit it as guys, but we still need to learn how to manage responsibility, how to face our challenges.
quotes.Title: Canadian Actor
quotes.Name: Ryan Reynolds

quotes.Text: It's possible - you can never know - that the universe exists only for me. If so, it's sure going well for me, I must admit.
quotes.Title: American Businessman
quotes.Name: Bill Gates

quotes.Text: Some desire is necessary to keep life in motion, and he whose real wants are supplied must admit those of fancy.
quotes.Title: English Writer
quotes.Name: Samuel Johnson

quotes.Text: I suppose I shouldn't go around admitting I speak untruths on the radio.
quotes.Title: American Journalist
quotes.Name: Ira Glass

quotes.Text: Mistakes are always forgivable, if one has the courage to admit them.
quotes.Title: American Actor
quotes.Name: Bruce Lee

quotes.Text: I guess I lead a double life, and I must admit I'm happy with both.
quotes.Title: Canadian Actress
quotes.Name: Yvonne De Carlo

quotes.Text: I am not the humblest person in the world. I admit that.
quotes.Title: Portuguese Footballer
quotes.Name: Cristiano Ronaldo

quotes.Text: Remembering in an honest way means admitting the truth.
quotes.Title: Austrian Politician
quotes.Name: Sebastian Kurz

quotes.Text: Don't be afraid to admit what your dreams are.
quotes.Title: Actress
quotes.Name: Jacqueline Fernandez
